required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Consequences of Parenteral Nutrition Photoprotection on Oxidant Related Diseases Among Extremely Low Birth Weight Infants
clinical_study.official_title: Consequences of Parenteral Nutrition Photoprotection on the Oxidant Related Diseases Among Extremely Low Birth Weight Infants : A Randomized Controlled Study

brief_summary.textblock: The antioxidant system of very low birth weight infants is immature. This immaturity is implicated in the pathogenesis of diseases such as bronchopulmonary dysplasia or retinopathy. The main source of oxidant is oxygen, and parenteral nutrition is contaminated with oxidant. Photoprotection decreases the oxidant load infused with parenteral nutrition. In a preliminary study, photoprotection reduced the frequency of pulmonary bronchodysplasia, increased the quantity of enteral nutrition tolerated, and decreased the arterial blood pressure among very low birth weight infants. The aim of this study is to evaluate the impact of photoprotection on oxidant related diseases among very low birth weight infants. This study is a randomized multicenter trial. In the intervention group, photoprotection is applied until the infusion of parenteral nutrition with amber bags, tubing, and syringes. The quality of photoprotection is controlled by measuring malondialdehyde and cysteine after 24 hours of infusion. The control group will receive parenteral nutrition with transparent bags and tubing. The outcomes are evaluated at 36 weeks, and 680 infants will be enrolled, with stratification among centers and gestational age.

primary_outcome.measure: Death or bronchopulmonary dysplasia at 28 days

intervention.description: use of photoprotected parenteral nutrition device
Use of standard (transparent) parenteral nutrition device

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Infants born before 30 weeks gestational age
- Postnatal age between 1 and 6 days
- Apgar score up to 2
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe congenital abnormalities
- Intraventricular hemorrhage grade up to 2
- Proven sepsis before inclusion
- Transfusion before inclusion
- Use of intravenous lipids or parenteral nutrition before randomisation

results_reference.citation: Laborie S, Denis A, Dassieu G, Bedu A, Tourneux P, Pinquier D, Kermorvant E, Millet V, Klosowski S, Patural H, Clamadieu C, Brunhes A, Walther M, Jaisson-Hot I, Mandy B, Claris O. Shielding Parenteral Nutrition Solutions From Light: A Randomized Controlled Trial. JPEN J Parenter Enteral Nutr. 2015 Aug;39(6):729-37. doi: 10.1177/0148607114537523. Epub 2014 Jun 12.
